<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 880, 636]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 664, 212, 678]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 680, 728, 711]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 72, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 72, 445, 90]]<|/det|>
For a set of 40 values of \(x\), it is found that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[322, 102, 677, 121]]<|/det|>
\[\Sigma (x - k) = 836.0,\qquad \Sigma (x - k)^2 = 25410.8,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 135, 288, 152]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 166, 148, 184]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 166, 682, 184]]<|/det|>
Given that the mean of these 40 values is 124.0, find the value of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 166, 920, 184]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 917, 432]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 444, 148, 463]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 444, 556, 463]]<|/det|>
Find the standard deviation of these 40 values of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 444, 920, 463]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
At a large college, all students who study Science also study exactly one of Art or Drama or Music. \(20\%\) of these students study Art, \(45\%\) study Drama and \(35\%\) study Music.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 144, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 120, 710, 136]]<|/det|>
3 students are selected at random from the students who study Science.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 150, 675, 167]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that at least 1 of these students studies Drama.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 151, 920, 167]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 915, 440]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 459, 146, 476]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 459, 720, 476]]<|/det|>
10 students are selected at random from the students who study Science.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 490, 600, 507]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that more than 7 study Art or Music.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 490, 920, 507]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 520, 915, 945]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
A fair six-sided dice with faces labelled 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 is thrown repeatedly until a 3 is obtained. The number of throws taken is denoted by the random variable \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 146, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 277, 136]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{P}(X = 8)\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 304, 146, 320]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 304, 280, 320]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{P}(X < 9)\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 304, 918, 320]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 552, 146, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 552, 784, 570]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that a 3 is obtained for the second time before the 6th throw.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 552, 918, 570]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
84 people attempt a particular puzzle. The times taken, in minutes, to complete the puzzle are recorded. These times are represented in the cumulative frequency graph below.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[170, 128, 825, 520]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 555, 148, 573]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 555, 918, 588]]<|/det|>
Use the graph to estimate how many people took between 4 and 7.5 minutes to complete the puzzle. [1]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 598, 918, 935]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
On the grid below, draw a box-and-whisker plot to summarise the information in the cumulative frequency graph.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 85, 918, 103]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[205, 112, 789, 325]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 401, 917, 945]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[826, 945, 917, 961]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Turn over]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 630, 90]]<|/det|>
Bag \(A\) contains 6 red marbles, 5 blue marbles and 1 green marble.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 505, 121]]<|/det|>
Bag \(B\) contains 5 red marbles and 3 blue marbles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 606, 152]]<|/det|>
A marble is chosen at random from bag \(A\) and placed in bag \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 166, 487, 183]]<|/det|>
A marble is now chosen at random from bag \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 197, 146, 215]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 197, 848, 215]]<|/det|>
Draw a tree diagram to represent this information, giving the probability on each branch. [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 670, 90]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that both marbles chosen are the same colour.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 918, 90]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 917, 432]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 444, 144, 462]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 444, 918, 476]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the marble chosen from bag \(A\) is blue, given that the marble chosen from bag \(B\) is blue.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 457, 918, 476]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
A company sells bags of pasta. The masses of large bags of pasta are normally distributed with mean \(2.50\mathrm{kg}\) and standard deviation \(0.12\mathrm{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 144, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 119, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the mass of pasta in a randomly chosen large bag is less than \(2.65\mathrm{kg}\).  [2]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 148, 915, 401]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 418, 581, 435]]<|/det|>
A restaurant manager buys 160 of these large bags of pasta.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 450, 146, 467]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 450, 918, 481]]<|/det|>
Find the number of bags for which you would expect the mass of pasta to be more than 1.65 standard deviations above the mean.  [3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 495, 915, 925]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 918, 121]]<|/det|>
The masses of small bags of pasta sold by the company are normally distributed with mean \(\mu \mathrm{kg}\) and standard deviation \(\sigma \mathrm{kg}\). Tests show that \(77\%\) of these bags have masses greater than \(1.26\mathrm{kg}\), and \(44\%\) have masses less than \(1.35\mathrm{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 136, 146, 154]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 135, 584, 153]]<|/det|>
Find, in either order, the value of \(\mu\) and the value of \(\sigma\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 135, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 166, 917, 935]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 902, 90]]<|/det|>
A set of friends consists of 7 men and 4 women. Three of the men are brothers: Ali, Ben and Charlie.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 146, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 104, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
Find the number of different arrangements of the 7 men in a line in which Ali and Ben do **not** stand next to each other. [3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 148, 915, 448]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 459, 146, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 459, 918, 492]]<|/det|>
Find the number of different arrangements of the 7 men and 4 women in a line in which all the men stand together and all the women stand together. [3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 505, 915, 920]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 144, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
In how many ways can the 7 men and 4 women be divided into a group of 6, a group of 3 and a group of 2 if there are no restrictions?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 85, 918, 103]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 114, 917, 415]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 428, 146, 446]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 428, 900, 446]]<|/det|>
The 7 men and 4 women are divided at random into a group of 6, a group of 3 and a group of 2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 459, 712, 477]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that Ali, Ben and Charlie are all in the same group.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 459, 918, 477]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 488, 917, 945]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 72, 566, 88]]<|/det|>
